Scheme 1 Carbon nanoplating stabilization of hierarchical MXene@C@MnO2 catalyst for effective Fenton-like reaction Sisheng Guo Yuqi Zheng Xinyue Zhang Xinying Lei Hongfei Sun Tao Wen ⁎ MOE Key Laboratory of Resources and Environmental Systems Optimization, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Beijing 102206, PR China MOE Key Laboratory of Resources and Environmental Systems Optimization, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, North China Electric Power University Beijing 102206 PR China MOE Key Laboratory of Resources and Environmental Systems Optimization, College of Environmental Science and Engineering, North China Electric Power University, Beijing, 102206, P.R. China ⁎ Corresponding author. MXenes materials are burgeoning candidates for advanced water purification. However, the self-restacking and surface passivation of MXenes severely hamper the utilization of their electronic properties and surface reactivity. Herein, we employed the strategy of carbon nanoplating stabilization of MXenes for not only effectively stabilizing the structure of MXenes but also providing nucleation growth of MnO2. The MXene@C@MnO2-activated PMS system was able to degrade ∼ 100% of bisphenol A (BPA) (20 mg/L) within 4 min with the turnover frequency (TOF) of 8.14 min−1. Specifically, the generation of superoxide radicals by activation of peroxymonosulfate (PMS) through reversible redox cycling between Mn(IV) and Mn(III) cations was regarded as the crucial driver of BPA removal. The scale-up experiment in actual water bodies achieved more than 90% BPA removal at 1200-bed volumes with stable catalytic properties during 20 h continuous operation. This work offers a potential macroscopic MXene-based nanohybrids for advanced oxidation processes. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords MXene@C@MnO2 nanohybrides Peroxymonosulfate Fenton-like reaction Superoxide radicals Wastewater remediation Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction With the intensification of organic micropollutants from industry and consumers, the growing scarcity of clean water energy systems has dramatically stimulated the advancement of water purification technologies over the past decades [1]. The promising heterogeneous advanced oxidation processes (AOPs), which degrade and mineralize organic micropollutants by generating reactive oxygen species (ROS), have received considerable attention to achieve unselective oxidation of a multitude of organic micropollutants in the water body [2,3]. Compared to •OH radical (< 1 μs and 2.7 V) in H2O2-mediated Fenton reactions, the sulfate radical (SO4 •-) with longer half-life (30–40 μs) and higher oxidation potential (2.5–3.1 V) endow the persulfate-based Fenton-like oxidation technology to achieve a broader application prospect [4,5]. In addition, persulfate-based processes present a wider pH operating condition. Among the commercial oxidants, such as H2O2, ozone (O3), peroxydisulfate (PDS) and peroxymonosulfate (PMS), the asymmetric structure of PMS (HSO5 −) molecule can be adsorbed readily on the catalyst surface and accompanied with the electron transfer from the catalytic active site to yield highly active hydroxyl (•OH) and sulfate radical (SO4 •−) owing to the existence of peroxo bond (O-O), which in turn produce singlet oxygen (1O2) and/or superoxide radical (O2 •−) [6–8]. Nevertheless, the insufficient exposure of the active sites of the heterogeneous catalysts renders a low activation efficiency of the active oxygen species in this process [9]. Meanwhile, the mass transfer of most free ROS from the catalyst surface to the target pollutants is difficult to achieve via the traditional AOPs due to the self-quenching effect [10]. Therefore, it remains a great synthetic challenge for developing activators with outstanding catalytic activities. MXenes have recently emerged as a unique class of to-dimensional (2D) transition metal carbides that show great potential to address the above problems. Those can be manufactured by etching the A layer in MAX, in which M stands for the transition metal, A for the IIIA/IVA group element, and X for C/N [11]. The surface terminations, including -OH, -O, or -F are generated upon the etching process, which endows MXenes with more catalytic active sites and thus enhances the absorption of reactants or target molecules [12]. It also confers on MXenes rich chemistry, tunable properties, and a highly hydrophilic surface without depleting the electrical conductivity of the transition metal carbide, which is essential for the migration of electrons in composites [13]. These outstanding properties have led to a widespread application of MXene-based materials in the research of environmental remediation [14], carbon dioxide reduction [15], water splitting [16], and energy storage [17]. Unfortunately, the intense van der Waals interactions and hydrogen bonds between MXenes nanosheets result in the self-stacking of hierarchical structures, which severely affects their electron transport capacity and hinders the utilization of their functional surfaces to the fullest extent [18,19]. In addition, MXenes show poor oxygen resistance resulting from the exposure of majority of edge metal atoms on their surface in a thermodynamically metastable [20]. These atoms frequently react with surface-attached oxygen-containing groups or traces of oxygen in the atmosphere to transform spontaneously into a steadier oxide state, which drastically reduces the electrical conductivity of MXenes and their surface activity [21]. The passivation of the MXene surface renders them less effective in practical application scenarios, and these limitations have become a key factor in hindering the fabrication of MXene-based materials, understanding their physicochemical properties, and fully utilizing their surface activity. MXene-based material utilization will be significantly enhanced if MXenes can overcome the above limitations and be synergistically incorporated with other excellent components. According to the results of previous research [22–24], stabilizing the MXene by carbon nanoplating was considered as a promising scheme due to the structural stability of carbon materials. The carbon nanoplating layer can effectively restrain the surface oxidation and self-stacking of MXene nanosheets by supporting the detachment effect and reducibility [25]. In addition, the presence of the carbon layer can provide binding sites for metal oxides growth [11]. The synergistic effect of MXene and carbon layer can guarantee fast charge transfer [26]. Transition metal oxides have been widely reported for their excellent PMS activation properties and easy regeneration. The cations in transition metal-based catalysts may serve as promising active sites, expected to improve the catalytic performance [27]. Manganese oxides with multivalent nature and nonstoichiometric compositions have attracted increasing attention in the applications of catalysis and energy conversion [28,29]. Because of their widespread availability, low toxicity, and high catalytic performance, manganese oxides might be alternative catalysts activating PMS for the remediation of emerging organic micropollutants [30,31]. Manganese oxides can potently adsorb and activate PMS owing to the participation of labile oxygen and various oxidation states [32]. Simultaneously, it is possible for oxygen to participate in the redox reaction by reversible redox cycling between Mn(IV) and Mn(III) cations in MnO2, which enhances the catalytic activity [33]. Immobilization of MnO2 nanoparticles (NPs) onto conductive substrates such as carbon-stabilized Ti3C2 MXenes could potentially improve the dispersibility of the active sites and stability of the redox. Inspired by the good chemical stability of carbon materials and superior activities of MnO2, we have designed and successfully fabricated hierarchical MXene@C@MnO2 nanohybrids of size-uniformed MnO2 NPs distributed on carbon stabilized Ti3C2 MXene backbone. The whole fabrication process of MXene@C@MnO2 nanohybrids was illustrated in Scheme 1. Before synthesis, the Ti3C2 MXene nanosheet was prepared by selectively etching and exfoliating the Ti3AlC2 MAX phase using concentrated HF and tetramethylammonium hydroxide solution (TMAOH). The obtained product was re-dispersed in ascorbic acid solution to prevent the oxidation of Ti3C2 MXene nanosheets [34]. Subsequently, a two-step deposition process was performed: (i) carbon nanoplating on MXene scaffolds by polymerizing glucose at 180 °C, (ii) MnO2 NPs anchored onto MXene@C nanosheets at room temperature by immersing into KMnO4 aqueous solution. In the MXene@C@MnO2 multicomponent, the carbon coating not only considerably enhances the electron transport efficiency of the entire composite materials but also stabilizes the structure of MXene nanosheets as well as provides the binding sites of MnO2 growth by a redox reaction between MXene@C and KMnO4. MXene@C@MnO2 demonstrated excellent PMS activation performance in Fenton-like reactions, while effective degradation of organic micropollutants by reactive species was detected. A continuous flow Fenton reactor was constructed to demonstrate that MXene could remove pollutants from actual water bodies for extended periods of time. This work provides a new strategy for preparing MXene-based composites, which are expected to be used for the long-term treatment of organic pollutants in natural water bodies. 2 Experimental sections 2.1 Chemicals and materials The MAX (Ti3AlC2) material was obtained from Forsman Technology (Beijing) Co.,Ltd. The chemicals hydrofluoric acid (HF, AR, ≥40%), L-glucose (98%), potassium permanganate (KMnO4), tetramethylammonium hydroxide solution (TMAOH, AR, 25% aqueous solution), potassium monopersulfate triple salt (PMS), bisphenol A (BPA), tetracycline (TC), sunset yellow (SY), 2,4,6-trichlorophenol (2,4,6-TCP), ciprofloxacin (CIP), furfuryl alcohol (FFA) and p-benzoquinone (p-BQ) were offered by Aladdin Reagents (Shanghai) Co.,Ltd. Methanol (MeOH), tert-butyl alcohol (TBA) and all other chemicals were provided by Beijing Chemical Reagent Co.,Ltd. 5,5-Dimethyl-1-pyrroline N-oxide (DMPO) was acquired by Dojindo laboratories. All the other reagents were of analytical grades and utilized as received without further purification. Deionized water (>18.2 MΩ) was applied in this study. 2.2 Material synthesis 2.2.1 Synthesis of exfoliated MXene dispersion The synthesis of exfoliated Ti3C2T x dispersion was prepared by a modified wet etching Al layer form Ti3AlC2 MAX phase as reported by Naguib et al. [35]. In a classic procedure, the mixture of 1.0 g of commercial Ti3AlC2 and 20 mL HF (40 wt%) solution was stirred at 40 °C for 24 h. For the delamination of multi-layered Ti3C2T x , 50 mg of Ti3C2T x were dispersed into 1 mL TMAOH solution under N2 flow and magnetically stirred for 12 h at room temperature to enlarge the layer spacing. After the intercalation, TMAOH was cleaned up by solvent exchange with deionized water for 3–4 cycles. The above black solid was transferred and re-dispersed in 50 mL of pre-prepared ascorbic acid solution (1 mg/mL) to protect the edges of the MXene nanosheets. The exfoliated MXene dispersion was obtained by centrifuging the layered dispersion at 3500 rpm for 10 min to separate the stacking MXene. The concentration of 1.53 mg/mL exfoliated MXene dispersion was determined from the mass of MXene obtained by freeze-drying 50 mL of the solution in liquid nitrogen for at least three days to remove the moisture. 2.2.2 Synthesis of MXene@C The above prepared MXene dispersion (30 mL) was mixed with 0.03 M glucose solution by sonication and magnetic stirring, followed by hydrothermal treatment at 180 °C for 18 h. Carbon-coated MXene (MXene@C) sample was obtained by pyrolysis of the hydrothermal product in a quartz tubular furnace under N2 flow at 500 °C with a ramp rate of 5 °C min−1 for 3 h. 2.2.3 Synthesis of MXene@C@MnO2 For the synthesis of MXene@C@MnO2 sample, the MnO2 NPs were decorated onto MXene@C by in-situ redox reaction between carbon and KMnO4. Briefly, MXene@C was immersed into 0.03 M KMnO4 aqueous solution and stirred them for 18 h at room temperature. The obtained products were collected by performing multiple cycles of centrifugation-rinsing with deionized water and then dried under vacuum at 60 °C. 2.3 Materials characterization Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of all samples were collected on a Rigaku SmartLab SE diffractometer (Cu Kα, λ = 1.5406 nm) and operating at 40 kV and 40 mA. Related functional groups of these samples were examined by Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra using Thermal-Nicolet 380. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area and pore space were measured using the TriStar II (Micromeretics, USA) by N2 adsorption-desorption method. Scanning electron microscope (SEM) was measured on a Thermo Scientific Quattro ESEM electron microscope operating. Transmission electron microscope (TEM) and energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy were measured on Hitachi 7650 microscope transmission electron microscopic. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were collected on the PerkinElmer PHI 1600 spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, STA 2500) of samples were carried out in N2 gas at a heating rate 5 °C/min of under stable reaction conditions of 25–800 °C. Total organic carbon (TOC) of pollutants was examined by a TOC analyzer (TOC-VCPH, Shimadzu). And electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) techniques were conducted on a Bruker model ESP 300E spectrometer. 2.4 Experimental procedure and analysis The Fenton-like catalytic performances of as-prepared samples were evaluated by the elimination of organic pollutant in the presence of PMS. In a typical test, 10 mg of MXene@C@MnO2 was added to 50 mL of BPA solution (20 mg/L) under magnetic stirring. The Fenton-like reaction was triggered to start with the addition of 40 mg of PMS. At regular time interval, 1.5 mL aliquots of reaction solution were taken by syringe and immediately filtrated through a 0.22 µm polysulfone ether membrane filter for successive analysis. The concentration of BPA residue was determined by high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) using 70% methanol and 30% ultrapure water as mobile phases at a flow rate of 0.5 mL/min and an injection volume of 20 µL with a detection wavelength of 225 nm. The Fenton-like activity of the MXene@C@MnO2 was investigated using the adsorption-desorption curves without PMS as a reference. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization and Fenton-like catalytic performance The phases and crystal structures of the as-obtained samples were determined by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD), as plotted in Fig. 1a and S1. MAX (Ti3AlC2) and MXene exhibited completely dissimilar characteristic peaks: the disappearance of characteristic (104) peak and the shift of (002) peak (2θ = 9.6°) to a lower angle (2θ = 6.1°), arising from the successful Al etching and interpolation of TMAOH [36]. After carbon coating on the surface of MXene, a broad diffraction peak centered at around 26° could be indexed to amorphous carbon in the PXRD pattern of MXene@C [37]. It is worth mentioning that with the disappearance of the (002) peak, the restacking of layered MXene was significantly inhibited by carbon layer coating on the surface and MnO2 deposition. Meanwhile, a new weak characteristic peak of MXene@C is a (101) peak belonging to TiO2, which is caused by the MXene oxidation during the hydrothermal process. Note that the PXRD pattern of MXene@C@MnO2 showed a significant enhancement of the (101) peak belonging to TiO2 due to the further oxidation of MXene. This means that the highly oxidizing MnO4 − not only reacted with the coated carbon layer, but also further oxidized minor amounts of Ti on the MXene surface to TiO2. Interestingly, after decorating the MnO2 NPs coating onto these MXene@C, an obvious Mn 2p signal appeared in the full scale XPS survey (Fig. 1b). Yet, the corresponding characteristic peaks of MnO2 were absent in the PXRD pattern of MXene@C@MnO2. This is presumably attributed to the relatively low content of nanoscale MnO2 particles, and the content of the partially amorphous phase was too low to display intense diffraction peaks [38]. The corresponding activity trends of these catalysts were investigated in PMS-assisted Fenton-like reaction for BPA degradation. As shown in Fig. 1c, a blank experiment in the presence of only PMS was also performed as a control. It is evident that the BPA was rarely degraded in the existence of PMS alone. And the adsorption-desorption test of BPA onto pure MXene@C@MnO2 revealed that the sample had limited adsorption of BPA, as evidenced by the inferior adsorption efficiency of only 26.4% within 10 min. Apparently, MXene@C@MnO2 has a significantly enhanced catalytic activity with the addition of PMS oxidants. Surprisingly, 100% of BPA could be degraded in 4 min using MXene@C@MnO2 as the activator, whereas pure MnO2, MXene, MXene@C, and MXene@MnO2 catalysts showed inferior activities of 75.5% 22.1%, 26.4% and 86.8%, respectively. The degradation kinetics were simulated using the pseudo-first-order kinetic model in order to visualize these catalytic systems more intuitively (Fig. 1d). Under identical conditions, the primary rate constant of the MXene@C@MnO2 +PMS reaction system reached a high of 1.629 min−1 (R 2 = 0.979) with the turnover frequency (TOF) of 8.14 min−1. Compared the catalytic performance of MXene@C@MnO2 with other previously reported catalysts, MXene@C@MnO2 exhibited considerable TOF over other manganese oxide-based materials or even close to single-atom catalysts [39–46] (Table S1). Like most MXene with HF etching treatment followed by TMAOH intercalation, scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images ( Fig. 2a) showed that MXene exhibited a typical “accordion” morphology, which enlarged the dense layer becoming more open with respect to the tightly compacted layered structure of MAX [47]. Following the carbon-coating treatment, the morphology of MXene@C maintained a multi-layered hierarchical structure while the sample surface became rough (Fig. 2b). Through further deposition process, the dense MnO2 NPs were immaculately anchored on the MXene@C sample surface as evidenced in the SEM and TEM images (Fig. 2c and d). Additionally, Fig. 2e showed the high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) images to further analyze the morphological and structural characterizations of MXene@C@MnO2. It was found that a continuous but very thin carbon layer combined with a large amount of nano-sized MnO2 randomly aligned on the surface was preserved. As depicted in Fig. 2f, the lattice fringes with spacings of 0.32 and 0.18 nm were observed, suggesting the preservation of the highly crystalline nature of MXene, which is related to the (008) and (110) crystal planes, respectively. Furthermore, the lattice stripe spacing of 0.36 nm, which was ascribed to the (101) plane of TiO2, revealed the partially oxidation of the Ti element, which completely overlaps with the PXRD results. Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) elemental mapping images ( Fig. 3a-f) clearly revealed the coexistence and uniform dispersion of C, Ti, Mn, and O elements in the whole MXene@C@MnO2. The agglomeration of Mn in MXene@C@MnO2 was suppressed distinctly, which would be a favorable factor for improving the catalytic activity of Fenton-like catalysts. In order to study the change of chemical states during the synthesis of the samples, valence analysis of the surface elements of MXene, MXene@C, and MXene@C@MnO2 was conducted using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). As displayed in Fig. 4a, by comparison of the high-resolution C 1 s XPS spectra of these samples, the peaks at 282.1 and 284.8 eV were attributed to C-Ti and surface adventitious carbon (C-C), while the C 1 s spectrum of MXene@C showed the enhanced C-C and the vanishing of C-Ti signals accompanying with the appearance of C-O peak at 285.2 eV, indicating the triumphant encapsulation of the carbon layer on the MXene surface. Furthermore, the weakening of the C-C peak and the appearance of a weak carboxyl carbon (CO) signal at 288.6 eV in MXene@C@MnO2 confirmed that MnO2 NPs were successfully anchored on the MXene@C surface by oxidizing the carbon layer on the MXene surface via MnO4 −. The high-resolution O 1 s XPS spectra of MXene and MXene@C samples were deconvolved into three peaks, as displayed in Fig. 4b. The peaks in the O 1 s spectrum of MXene@C were ascribed to Ti-O (529.9 eV), Ti–OH (531.5 eV), and C–OH (532.8 eV), and their counterparts in the O 1 s spectrum of pristine MXene were located at 529.9, 531.6, and 533.1 eV, respectively. The simultaneous appearance of new signals at 529.4 and 531.1 eV after the loading of MnO2 was attributed to Mn-O and Mn-OH species, which is congruent with previously published studies [48,49]. In addition, the Ti 2p core energy level fitted by the deconvolution of the three doublets demonstrated the typical XPS signal of the Ti element in MXene, as shown in Fig. 4c. Three peaks located at 454.9, 455.5, and 456.7 eV were affiliated to Ti-C, Ti(III) and Ti-O in the Ti 2p3/2 fine spectrum, respectively. Surprisingly, the Ti 2p core energy level in MXene was replaced by TiO2 in the MXene@C by the subsequent reaction, showing two peaks of Ti 2p centered at 459.6 and 465.3 eV belong to Ti 2p3/2 and Ti 2p1/2, respectively. Notably, the binding energies (BEs) of Ti 2p underwent a remarkably negative shift after anchoring MnO2 NPs on MXene@C, demonstrating the electron transfer at the MXene interface (Fig. 4d). A subsequent in-depth investigation of Mn valence states in MXene@C@MnO2 was presented in Fig. 4e and f. Two peaks located at 642.2 and 653.9 eV were categorized as the spin-orbit doublet states of Mn 2p3/2 and Mn 2p1/2, differing in spin energy by 11.7 eV, which is in good agreement with the phase of MnO2 thus determining the successful loading of MnO2 nanoparticles [50]. The Spectrum fitting of Mn 2p3/2 revealed the presence of Mn(IV) (641.8 eV) and Mn(III) (643.2 eV) [51]. Meanwhile, the average valence state of Mn in MXene@C@MnO2 was 3.6, which can be calculated from the Mn 3 s peak splitting energy of 4.7 eV [52]. Generally, the presence of low valent Mn implies the forming of crystal defects, which can trap larger amounts of electrons and supply additional active sites for the activation of reactive substances, facilitating Fenton-like reactions [53]. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectroscopy was employed to further investigate the chemical environment of the samples. As indicated in Fig. S2, the broad band at 3200–3600 cm−1 originated from the surface hydroxyl groups [54]. Meanwhile, the generation of broad characteristic peaks in the 2800–3000 cm−1 region might be due to the stretching vibration of the Ti-C-Ti skeleton [55]. The signal at 514 cm−1 belonging to Mn-O confirmed the successful anchoring of MnO2 NPs [56]. The porosities of these catalysts were further probed by N2 adsorption-desorption studies. As illustrated in Fig. S3a, it was found that MXene@C@MnO2 exhibited a distinct type IV isotherm with H3-type hysteresis loop, which is correlated with capillary condensation occurring in mesopores. Both MXene@C and MXene@C@MnO2 displayed similarly mesoporous material with slit-shaped pores [57]. Moreover, the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface area of MXene, MXene@C, and MXene@C@MnO2 were estimated as 61, 217, and 128 m2/g, respectively. On the basis of the desorption isotherms using the Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method, the pore size distributions of three samples were concentrated at 2.94, 2.45, and 4.10 nm (Fig. S3b), respectively. Fig. S4 shows the thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) curves performed from room temperature to 800 °C in N2 atmosphere. The mass of MXene itself remained almost unchanged, and the weight loss of MXene@C and MXene@C@MnO2 above 500 °C was attributed to the decomposition of the surface oxygen and carbon layers. For MXene@C@MnO2, the weight loss from room temperature is attributed to the large amount of physically adsorbed water on the sample surface and functional groups such as surface hydroxyl groups [58]. The final weight loss values were calculated to be 2.30%, 15.93% and 29.34% for the MXene, MXene@C and MXene@C@MnO2 samples, respectively. 3.2 Performances of MXene@C@MnO2 in Fenton-like reactions The exploration of optimal operating conditions for these MXene-based catalysts is necessary for reaching the best Fenton-like degradation performance of bisphenol A (BPA). The impact of the MXene@C@MnO2 dose was investigated, as shown in Fig. 5a. BPA was completely degraded in 4 min when the amount of catalyst was raised from 0.2 to 1.5 g/L. The concentration of MXene@C@MnO2 was established at 0.2 g/L in the perspective of saving the cost of the Fenton-like process. Furthermore, the optimum amount of the PMS was determined (Fig. 5b). The degradation efficiency of BPA improved as the concentration of PMS reached from 0.1 to 0.8 g/L. After that, the BPA no longer degraded by augmenting the content of PMS. Investigating the performance of as-prepared catalysts for BPA degradation by activating PMS at different pH is indispensable because the conventional homogeneous Fenton process suffers from the inherent bottleneck of a narrow working pH range [59]. The variation of solution pH values on the degradation of BPA is displayed in Fig. 5c. The degradation efficiency of MXene@C@MnO2 for BPA was still able to reach 100% in a wide pH range (pH=2.5–10.5), indicating that MXene@C@MnO2 exhibited excellent catalytic activity under basic, neutral and acidic conditions. It was noteworthy that the degradation rate of BPA showed a significant decrease when the solution was neutral and basic (Fig. S5), which may be accounted for the fact that PMS was readily hydrolyzed to SO5 − under this condition, whose oxidizing capacity was much lower than that of SO4 •− [60]. In reality, the background substances in the water body could unavoidably influence the degradation efficiency of the Fenton-like reaction. Natural organic matter such as inorganic anions (Cl−, HCO3 −, and NO3 −) and humic acid (HA) was added into the MXene@C@MnO2 +PMS system to analyze the system's anti-interference ability. As indicated in Fig. 5d, the effects of NO3 − and HA on the MXene@C@MnO2 +PMS system were negligible. However, Cl− and HCO3 − demonstrated a significant impact on the performance of the system. With the addition of Cl− anions, the almost instantaneous degradation of BPA might be attributed to the dual role of Cl− in the activation of PMS. For one, the radicals such as ClOH•− (1.5–1.8 V), Cl2 •− (2.0 V), and Cl• (2.47 V) with high oxidation potentials may be generated by the reaction of Cl− with SO4 •− and •OH, which could substantially speed up the degradation of BPA [61]. In addition, since the homogeneous reaction is faster than the reaction at the solid-liquid interface, the HOCl may be generated through Cl− reacting directly with PMS, which converts BPA to other byproducts [62]. In contrast, the presence of HCO3 − suppressed the degradation of BPA. This result indicated that HCO3 − can react with PMS molecules, but the produced HCO3 • with a low oxidation potential (1.6 V) was unable to oxidize BPA effectively. There is also a possible reason that the hydrolysis of HCO3 − leads to the alkaline nature of the reaction system, and the electrostatic repulsion between MXene@C@MnO2, PMS, and BPA is enhanced under basic conditions, as a result of inferior reactivity of the system [61]. In conclusion, the overall oxidation efficiency of BPA remains satisfactory, which implies the excellent interference resistance of MXene@C@MnO2 and its promising application in practical wastewater treatment. To further validate the excellent immunity to interference in practical water bodies, the degradation properties of BPA in the MXene@C@MnO2 +PMS system were tested in river water taken from the Jingmi Diversion Canal and tap water. It is obviously shown that the MXene@C@MnO2 +PMS system presented a decreased degradation rate of BPA under the combined effect of inorganic ions, natural organic matter and microbiota, but was still able to remove it entirely within 8 min (Fig. 5e). The universality of MXene@C@MnO2 for the degradation of other common organic micropollutants was also investigated. Impressively, MXene@C@MnO2 exhibited excellent degradation of SY, 2,4,6-TCP, TC, and CIP (Fig. 5f). Meanwhile, TOC removal tests of these micropollutants were carried out (Fig. S6). The corresponding mineralization efficiencies of BPA, SY, 2,4,6-TCP, TC, and CIP reached 62.0%, 36.5%, 46.1%, 48.4%, and 11.4% in the MXene@C@MnO2 +PMS system. Surprisingly, TC was completely degraded almost instantaneously, which may be due to the fact that TC with electron donors (amido and hydroxyl groups) was more easily oxidized by reactive substances. Summarizing, the MXene@C@MnO2 +PMS system showed stable degradation performance in a variety of environments, and also exhibited significant removal of a broad range of micropollutants in wastewater. 3.3 Identification of reactive species Radical quenching experiments and EPR were implemented in order to reveal the ROS generated during the PMS activation process. In general, TBA and MeOH were used to quench •OH and SO4 •− radicals, respectively, while superoxide radicals (O2 •−) and single linear oxygen (1O2) were quenched using p-BQ and FFA [63,64]. As shown in Fig. 6a, the efficiency of the reaction system to degrade BPA decreased only in the existence of p-BQ, with a degradation efficiency of 79.5% at 10 min, while no distinct influence was observed with the other quenchers for BPA degradation. For excluding the removal of BPA by the presence of high valent metal oxides in the reaction system, dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) was used to quench the high-valent Mn-oxo species (i.e., Mn(VI) and Mn(V)). The results revealed that DMSO did not provide any action. Subsequently, the degradation efficiency of BPA was only 2.3% after 10 min when the p-BQ concentration was increased to 50 mM (Fig. S7). From this outcome, it can be concluded that the degradation of BPA in the reaction system was almost entirely caused by O2 •−. In order to further determine the active species for the removal of BPA, DMPO and TEMP trapped EPR experiments were undertaken. As shown in Fig. 6b, the weak DMPO-•OH adducts signals could be detected in the absence of catalysts indicating that •OH could be produced by hydrolysis of HSO5 − [43], whereas the DMPO-•OH signals produced by MXene@C@MnO2 alone could be caused by the presence of abundant hydroxyl groups on the material surface. Under the same conditions, the weak DMPO-SO4 •− signal and the enhanced DMPO-•OH signal appeared in the MXene+PMS system, implying that MXene can activate PMS but with limited capacity. For the MXene@C@MnO2 +PMS system, the characteristic signals with the peak intensity of 1:2:1:2:1:2:1 were measured belonging to 5,5-dimethyl-2-pyrrolidone-N-oxyl (DMPOX), which constitutes the direct oxidation derivative of DMPO. The presence of DMPOX was commonly considered to be produced by the oxidation of DMPO with a large number of oxidants, indicating that the reaction system was enriched with significant amounts of reactive substances. Moreover, it was evident that O2 •− was produced by MXene@C@MnO2 activated PMS upon comparison with the EPR of other systems as shown in Fig. 6c. In contrast, as presented in Fig. S8, the signals of 1O2 did not exhibit any enhancement following the incorporation of MXene@C@MnO2 into the reaction system. According to the above quenching experiments and EPR characterization, it was demonstrated that O2 •− radicals are the major ROS produced in the MXene@C@MnO2 +PMS system, and the key to the efficient degradation of BPA. On this basis, the possible degradation mechanism of BPA in Fenton-like catalytic system of MXene@C@MnO2 +PMS was proposed (Fig. 6d). PMS was adsorbed onto the catalyst surface, and then Mn(III) activated the HSO5 − to produce O2 •− via electron transfer. The Mn(IV) formed in this process could be reduced to Mn(III) by PMS to reclaim the catalyst and release O2 •− again. The corresponding reaction can be seen in the following Eqs. (1) and (2). (1) Mn III + 2 HSO 5 − → Mn IV + O 2 • − + 2 HSO 4 − (2) Mn IV + HSO 5 − + H 2 O → Mn III + O 2 • − + 3 H + + SO 4 2 − 3.4 Recycling performance The Fenton-like catalytic experiments with four consecutive regeneration cycles were conducted to evaluate the reusability of MXene@C@MnO2. As illustrated in Fig. 7c, the catalytic degradation process could be cycled at least four times without noticeable influence of BPA degradation. MXene@C@MnO2 maintained a high elimination efficiency-on average 99%. All these results proved that the MXene@C@MnO2 +PMS Fenton reaction not only achieved the excellent stability and reusability but also faster kinetics. 3.5 Water treatment applications In order to evaluate the performance of MXene@C@MnO2 for continuous treatment of pollutants in real water bodies, a simple continuous flow Fenton reactor was constructed with vacuum filtration of the MXene@C@MnO2 onto a polyvinylidene difluoride (PVDF) membrane. The PMS and the wastewater were pumped into the continuous flow reactor and the mixed solution was passed through the MXene@C@MnO2 membrane to trigger the Fenton reaction (Fig. 7a). The MXene@C@MnO2 membrane exhibits good flexibility as displayed in Fig. 7b. The BPA removal efficiencies of both MXene and MXene@C were consistently below 19%. Comparatively, the degradation efficiency of BPA by MXene@C@MnO2 could still be maintained above 90% at 1200 bed volumes after a long period of continuous operation for 20 h (Fig. 7d). This suggests that MXene could continuously activate PMS to produce ROS, leading to the continuous and effective degradation of contaminants in solution. Further, MXene@C@MnO2 holds great promise for practical wastewater treatment. 4 Conclusions In summary, we demonstrate a promising strategy to enhance the Fenton-like catalytic performance of MXene by coating a carbon layer on MXene to assist in anchoring MnO2 nanoparticles. The original layered structure of MXene is still retained in the carbon layer-coated MXene despite that Ti was partially oxidized to TiO2, which provides a wider potential for the deposition of MnO2 on the surface of MXene@C. The hybrid Mn(IV)/Mn(III) couple has an extremely significant impact on the activation of PMS by MXene@C@MnO2. Experimental evidence confirmed that MXene@C@MnO2 has excellent PMS activation properties, and the MXene@C@MnO2 mediated Fenton-like reaction produced massive O2 •− leading to the efficient removal of a variety of organic micropollutants in wastewater. Meanwhile, MXene@C@MnO2 has a wide range of applications in real water bodies owing to its excellent anti-interference properties. The scale-up experiment in actual water bodies achieved more than 90% BPA removal at 1200-bed volumes with stable catalytic properties during 20 h continuous operation. This work establishes a new strategy for the reasonable design of MXene-based materials and the improvement of the catalytic properties of heterogeneous Fenton-like catalysts. coredata.dc:description: MXenes materials are burgeoning candidates for advanced water purification. However, the self-restacking and surface passivation of MXenes severely hamper the utilization of their electronic properties and surface reactivity. Herein, we employed the strategy of carbon nanoplating stabilization of MXenes for not only effectively stabilizing the structure of MXenes but also providing nucleation growth of MnO2. The MXene@C@MnO2-activated PMS system was able to degrade ∼ 100% of bisphenol A (BPA) (20 mg/L) within 4 min with the turnover frequency (TOF) of 8.14 min−1. Specifically, the generation of superoxide radicals by activation of peroxymonosulfate (PMS) through reversible redox cycling between Mn(IV) and Mn(III) cations was regarded as the crucial driver of BPA removal. The scale-up experiment in actual water bodies achieved more than 90% BPA removal at 1200-bed volumes with stable catalytic properties during 20 h continuous operation. This work offers a potential macroscopic MXene-based nanohybrids for advanced oxidation processes.
coredata.dc:title: Carbon nanoplating stabilization of hierarchical MXene@C@MnO2 catalyst for effective Fenton-like reaction
